CompetitionName: INDIA WOMEN TOUR OF NEW ZEALAND  ONLY WT20I 2022
Comments: New Zealand Women Won by 18  Runs
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the Only WT20I between India Women and New Zealand Women at the John Davies Oval, Queenstown. The T20I is the curtain-raiser to an exciting series that includes 5 One-Day Internationals, culminating in the Women's World Cup in New Zealand in March. 

TOSS: India have won the toss and opted to field first.

 

Playing XI:

India: H Kaur (c), D Sharma, R Ghosh (wk), S Verma, Y Bhatia, S Meghana, P Vastrakar, S Rana, R Gayakwad, S Bahadur, P Yadav 

New Zealand:  S Devine (c), S Bates, A Kerr, M Green, B Halliday, K Martin (wk), L Down, H Jensen, L Tahuhu, J Kerr, H Rowe
PostMatchCommentary:
New Zealand win the only WT20I by a margin of 18 runs after a fighting chase from India. After a good opening stand, Meghana injected momentum in India's innings but New Zealand's bowlers struck at regular intervals to restrict India to 137/8. Earlier, after being put into bat, Suzie Bates and Sophie Devine helped New Zealand to a strong start but India's bowlers pegged them back through the middle overs, before Lea Tahuhu's quick-fire 27 powered the hosts to 155/5 in 20 overs. 

 

Lea Tahuhu is named the player of the match for her 27(14b, 4x4,1x6) with the bat and 1/27 with the ball

 

Lea Tahuhu: "Not surprising for me to be promoted up, it's a plan we have talked about doing. It's a really good way to kick off what will be a really big couple of months for us. "

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, Captain, India: "I thought we were in the game when we were bowling but unfortunately the last few overs didn't go well. We did not have partnerships in batting as well. We have learnt a lot from this match and hope we will improve ourselves."

 

Sophie Devine, Captain, New Zealand: " It's awesome to lift the cup. It is the blueprint of how we want to play our T20 cricket. To get over 150 was a great score for us. With the ball we executed our plans clearly which was really good."

MatchName: New Zealand Women VS India Women

CompetitionName: INDIA WOMEN TOUR OF NEW ZEALAND ODI SERIES 2022
Comments: New Zealand Women Won by 62 Runs
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and Welcome to the live commentary of the first of five WODIs between India and New Zealand. Mithali Raj's side will be eager to acclimatize themselves to conditions quickly as they continue preparations for the Women's World Cup, while the hosts will look to take confidence from the win in the only WT20I between these two sides on Wednesday into the 50-over series. All matches will be held at John Davies Oval, Queenstown. 

 

Toss: India won the toss and elect to bowl first.

India XI: S Verma, Y Bhatia, M Raj (c), H Kaur, S Meghana, R Ghosh (wk), D Sharma, P Vastrakar, J Goswami, R Gayakwad, P Yadav 

New Zealand XI: S Devine (c), S Bates, A Kerr, A Satterthwaite, M Green, B Halliday, K Martin (wk), H Jensen, L Tahuhu, J Kerr, H Rowe
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :- 
New Zealand  -  48/0  ||  India - 29/2
 

Second Powerplay (11-40 Ov)
New Zealand  - 172/3 ||  India - 140/4
 

Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov)
New Zealand  - 55/7  ||  India - 44/4


New Zealand kickstart the five-match ODI series with a 62-run win against India. Yastika Bhatia and Mithali Raj provided a platform in the chase, but the White Ferns picked wickets at regular intervals as Jess Kerr scalped 4/35 for the hosts. Earlier, after being put in to bat, Suzie Bates struck a  magnificent ton at the top of the order, but the Indian bowlers pulled things back well towards the second half as Jhulan Goswami, Pooja Vastrakar, Rajeshwari Gayakwad, Deepti Sharma picked up 2 wickets a-piece. 


Mithali Raj, Captain, India: "It is very important to get used to the conditions. It is good we are playing a series before the World Cup.  We made a come back in the later half of the first innings. It took some time for the bowlers to get used to the conditions."


Sophie Devine, Captain, New Zealand: "It was nice to see Suzie Bates amongst the runs. Had to bowl into the wind as well, and we want people to adapt in to this team. Really pleased with the bowling effort, there is still room for improvement."


Suzie Bates is the Player of the Match for her 106 (111b, 10x4)


Suzie Bates: "It is a pretty special day, to start the series with a win and a hundred. We want to make sure we compete in every game throughout this series and heading into the World Cup. Proud of the way the team stood up today."

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the second WODI between India and New Zealand at John Davies Oval, Queenstown. The hosts won the first of the five-game ODI series with a 62-run margin as Suzie Bates scored a century and Jess Kerr picked up a 4-wicket haul. Mithali Raj's side fought back well with the ball, while the skipper's middle-order partnership with Yastika Bhatia in the chase should inject confidence.


Toss: India have won the toss and elected to bat. 


Playing XI: 

India: S Verma, Y Bhatia, M Raj (c), H Kaur, S Meghana, R Ghosh (wk), D Sharma, P Vastrakar, S Bahadur, R Gayakwad, P Yadav 

New Zealand: S Bates, M Green, A Kerr, A Satterthwaite (c), S Devine, B Halliday, K Martin (wk), H Jensen, R Mair, J Kerr, F Jonas
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :- 
New Zealand  -  57/3  ||  India - 57/0
 

Second Powerplay (11-25 Ov)
New Zealand  - 78/0 ||  India - 70/3


Second Powerplay (26-40 Ov)
New Zealand  - 78/3 ||  India - 76/1

Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov)
New Zealand  - 60/2  ||  India - 67/2

 

A neck and neck game that went right down to the wire but New Zealand hold their nerve for a 3-wicket win in the second WODI. Despite a rapid start, India scalped 3 big wickets of Sophie Devine, Suzie Bates and skipper Amy Satterthwaite within the first 10 overs. Amelia Kerr and Maddy Green then combined for a century stand, before the former brought up a fine hundred and remained unbeaten on 119 to guide the hosts home along with sister Jess Kerr. Earlier, after opting to bat first, it was a solid effort with the willow from India as they put on 270/6 in their 50 overs. Opening pair of Shafali Verma and S Meghana got the visitors off to an aggressive start, as the latter fell just short of a well-deserved maiden WODI half-century. Yastika Bhatia played her shots in a breezy innings, and then it was then the experienced Mithali Raj and young Richa Ghosh, both scoring 50s, who set the tone with a splendid century stand through the middle phase. 

Amelia Kerr is the Player of the Match.

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the third WODI between India and New Zealand. The picturesque John Davies Oval will play host to this must-win encounter for India after New Zealand secured a narrow 3-wicket win in the second game to go 2-0 in the five-game series. Amelia Kerr's century sealed a hard-fought win for the White Ferns on Tuesday after 50s from Mithali Raj and Richa Ghosh along with an aggressive start from Meghana helped India to a competitive total with the bat.

 

Toss: New Zealand win the toss and elect to bowl 

India XI: S Verma, S Meghana, Y Bhatia, M Raj (c), H Kaur, T Bhatia (wk), D Sharma, J Goswami, S Rana, R Thakur, E Bisht 

New Zealand XI: S Bates, S Devine (c), A Kerr, A Satterthwaite, M Green, L Down, K Martin (wk), F Mackay, L Tahuhu, H Rowe, R Mair
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :- 

India - 86/0 (8.6 rpo) || New Zealand - 58/2 (5.8 rpo)

Second Powerplay (11-25 Ov) :-

India - 72/3 (4.8 rpo) || New Zealand - 66/1 (4.4 rpo)

Second Powerplay (26-40 Ov) :-

India - 67/3 (4.5 rpo) || New Zealand - 92/3 (6.1 rpo)
Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov) :-

India - 54/4 (5.8 rpo) || New Zealand - 64/1 (7.0 rpo)

 

 

Another nail-biting encounter goes New Zealand's way as the White Ferns claim a close 3-wicket win in the third WODI! India struck early through Jhulan Goswami's excellent spell, Amelia Kerr & Amy Satterthwaite then stood firm with a century stand but India continued to chip away with the wickets. Lauren Down and Katey Martin then kept the scores ticking with a crucial 76-run partnership for New Zealand as the former remained unbeaten on 64 to chase with 5 balls to spare. Earlier, after being put into bat, S Meghana and Shafali Verma got India off to a flyer with a quick-fire century stand, before New Zealand pulled things back. Deepti Sharma then played anchor towards the later half, remaining unbeaten on 67* as India set a target of 280 for the hosts.

Lauren Down is named Player of the Match.

Lauren Down: "That was a bit of fun. Nice to guide the side home with the series win on the line. Great to see right across the series different people contributing. We didn't really feel pressure, at 152 for 4, we backed our batting order and talked about keeping it simple, taking the ones and twos, and trying to put the bad balls away. They (India) are a really quality side and they've got better with every game"

Mithali Raj, Captain, India: "We did not get the partnerships through the middle, Deepti's innings got us to 280. Every game the batting unit has been doing very well, there are a lot of areas we need to work on as a fielding unit."

Sophie Devine, Captain, New Zealand: "The cricket we have played over the last 3 games has been outstanding. Our challenge is now to continue. The way the batters handled the run chase was pleasing, at times things could have gotten away from us but the way Lauren Down and Frankie Mackay played were outstanding at the end, Amelia Kerr, Amy Satterthwaite, you could talk about all the batters. The way the team has grown over the last couple of years is that we don't get too nervous chasing big totals. We set ourselves very high standards, after their start to keep them under 300 was very good. Consistency is something we have screamed for, just need to tidy up few things. The way the team went about the chase was outstanding. We will reflect and celebrate, we should be very proud"

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the fourth WODI between India and New Zealand at John Davies Oval, Queenstown. The hosts took an unassailable 3-0 series lead after a thrilling win in the third WODI which went right down to the final over.  With the Women's World Cup just over a few weeks away, Mithali Raj-led team will look to fine-tune their preparations in the last two WODIs.

After an initial rain delay, the match has been reduced to 20 Overs between each side.

India has won the toss and elected to field first.

Playing XI:
India: S Verma, S Mandhana, Y Bhatia, M Raj (c), R Ghosh (wk), D Sharma, P Vastrakar, S Rana, R Thakur, M Singh, R Gayakwad
New Zealand: S Bates, S Devine (c), A Kerr, A Satterthwaite, L Down, K Martin (wk), F Mackay, H Jensen, H Rowe, R Mair, J Kerr
PostMatchCommentary:
REVISED PLAYING CONDITIONS:

 

Powerplay 1 (Overs 1-4):

New Zealand - 30/0 (7.5 rpo) ||  India - 18/3 (4.5 rpo)
Powerplay 2 (Overs 5-16):

New Zealand - 115/3 (9.6 rpo) ||  India - 99/3 (8.3 rpo)
Powerplay 3 (Overs 17-20):

New Zealand - 46/2 (11.5 rpo) ||  India - 11/4 (6.0 rpo)

 

Young Richa Ghosh smashed the fastest WODI fifty for Team India, but New Zealand sealed a rain-curtailed fourth WODI by 63 runs. After the game was reduced to 20 overs, the top order got New Zealand off to a quick start, before the Indian bowlers fought back with some tight spells. Amelia Kerr remained unbeaten on 33-ball 68 as the hosts set a target of 192 for India. In reply, after the loss of quick wickets, Richa Ghosh hammered 4 fours and 4 sixes, sharing a quick-fire half-century stand with Mithali Raj, but Amelia Kerr and Hayley Jensen took 6-wickets between them to go 4-0 up in the WODI series. 
 

Amelia Kerr is named the Player of the Match

Amelia Kerr: "Woke up this morning and didn't know whether we would get on, turned to a T20 match which is always fun with this group, it was nice to post a big score, the way Suzie, Sophie came out and then Amy got us to flyers, I just looked to carry that. I've done a lot of work through the winter on my batting, got trained as hard and as similar as I can to a game, had the opportunity to bat a lot, good preparation heading into the summer. Great to get 4 wins against a quality side, for us to come out and play well, especially with the bat, to have that belief and confidence is massive heading into the World cup."

Mithali Raj, Captain, India: "We have been trying a few different compositions to the seam and spin attack, to be honest, the bowling department is a bit of a concern ahead of the big event, we are 4 games in and we are trying to figure ways to get momentum. With this open ground, breeze, there are spells when bowlers bowl well but we have not been consistent. I was just looking at the shots Richa was playing, the way she had gone about her batting today, she is very talented and has a bright future for India."

Sophie Devine, Captain, New Zealand: "Complete performance from us, showed real intent in a shortened game, the way the batters went out there and played to their strengths, fielding is the area where we have missed fair few runs, with bowling, there are times where we have been slow to change our plans at times. Certainly had belief in this group, the way these girls have trained in the last couple of years, results may not have gone our way, but we are seeing results now, and with the World Cup around the corner it's real confidence."

MatchName: New Zealand Women VS India Women

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to live commentary of the fifth and final WODI between India and New Zealand at John Davies Oval, Queenstown. Richa Ghosh blasted the fastest half-century for Team India in WODIs in a rain-affected fourth game, but New Zealand's Amelia Kerr's all-round performance helped the hosts to a 63-run win. Mithali Raj's team will be eager to score a confidence-boosting win in the final encounter with the Women's World Cup just weeks away.

 

Toss: New Zealand won the toss and opt to bat

Playing XI:

India: S Verma, S Mandhana, M Raj (c), H Kaur, R Ghosh (wk), D Sharma, S Rana, J Goswami, M Singh, P Yadav, R Gayakwad 

New Zealand: S Bates, S Devine (c), A Kerr, A Satterthwaite, L Down, K Martin (wk), F Mackay, H Jensen, H Rowe, R Mair, F Jonas
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :- 

New Zealand  -  49/1 (4.9 rpo) ||  India - 53/1 (5.3 rpo)

Second Powerplay (11-25 Ov)

New Zealand  - 77/2 (5.1 rpo) ||  India - 75/1 (5 rpo)
Second Powerplay (26-40 Ov)

New Zealand  - 68/3 (4.5 rpo) ||  India - 82/1 (5.5 rpo)
Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov)

New Zealand  - 57/3 (5.7 rpo) ||  India - 45/1 (7.5 rpo)

 

India finish the tour on a high with a comprehensive 6-wicket win against New Zealand. After a breezy start from the openers, Smriti Mandhana (71 from 84b, 9x4) and Harmanpreet Kaur (63 from 66b, 6x4,1x6) steadied the ship with a 64-run stand for the third wicket, and once Smriti was dismissed, Harmanpreet and Mithali Raj (57* from 66b, 6x4) put up 72-run stand taking India closer to the target, with the Indian skipper steering them home with 4 overs to spare. Earlier after the hosts opted to bat first, it was an excellent display from the Indian bowlers to restrict the White Ferns to 251/9 with Rajeshwari Gayakwad, Deepti Sharma and Sneh Rana taking 6 wickets between them. Amelia Kerr top scored with 66.

 

Smriti Mandhana is named the Player of the Match

Smriti Mandhana: "It was an excellent performance from the bowlers to restrict them to 250, and the wicket was good to bat, all the batting unit contributed, all 3 of us could contribute and get a win. Initially, 10-15 balls were difficult, but the more time I spent, I got used to it. I think this series was a big advantage to get prepared for the World Cup, the team has been here before in 2019 and that will be an advantage. We have had close matches, all have contributed, the girls are confident and will think about this win and take this momentum into the World cup." 

 

Amelia Kerr is named the Player of the Series.

Amelia Kerr: "It's been awesome, loved it with the group in Queenstown and everybody has performed well and everyone is eager to get the World Cup. We know India are a quality side, we should take each game as it comes heading into the World Cup. I try to keep the same processes, play the ball on its merit, with the ball get the back leg through and keep the flight when I bowl best. I don't think it's tough batting and bowling, I've done it as a kid, now at the international level it's about doing the same, for me it's all about being competitive. I think we are heading in the right direction, we have belief as a group and that's very important. I don't think we have fielded as well we would have liked, we know how good we are, if we work on this we can save 20-30 runs in the field

PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the live coverage of the ICC Women's World Cup between India and Pakistan. Four years since the heart-breaking loss to England at the Home of Cricket in the finals of the mega event, the Indian team will look to go one step better this time, as they start their world cup journey against arch-rivals Pakistan at the Bay Oval. The Women in Blue were victorious in their last ODI match against New Zealand, and will look to use the experience of playing in these conditions to full effect.

Toss: India won the toss and opt to bat first

Playing XI:

India: Smriti Mandhana, Shafali Verma, Deepti Sharma, Harmanpreet Kaur, Mithali Raj (C), Richa Ghosh (WK), Sneh Rana, Jhulan Goswami, Meghna Singh, Pooja Vastrakar, Rajeshwari Gayakwad

Pakistan: Javeria Khan, Sidra Ameen, Bismah Maroof (C), Omaima Sohail, Nida Dar, Aliya Riaz, Fatima Sana, Sidra Nawaz (WK), Diana Baig, Nashra Sundhu, Anam Amin

India start their ICC Womens World Cup campaign with a 107 win against Pakistan. Earlier in the day, India won the toss and decided to bat first. Half-centuries from Smriti Mandhana, Pooja Vastrakar and Sneh Rana helped India score 244 in their fifty overs. In the second innings, Rajeshwari Gayakwad spun a web around the Pakistani batters. Sneh Rana and Jhulan Goswami chipped in with two wickets each and helped India bundle out Pakistan for 137 runs. 

Pooja Vastrakar is the player of the match for her well made 67(59)

PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of India's second match of the ICC Women's World Cup against hosts New Zealand, at Seddon Park in Hamilton. Pooja Vastrakar and Sneh Rana produced a match-defining partnership to help the Women in Blue start their campaign with a win, whereas the White Ferns bounced back against Bangladesh in a rain-affected encounter after a shocking loss to West Indies in their opening match.

TOSS:- India won the toss and elected to field.

PLAYING XI:-

India XI: Y Bhatia, S Mandhana, D Sharma, M Raj (c), H Kaur, R Ghosh (wk), S Rana, P Vastrakar, J Goswami, M Singh, R Gayakwad

New Zealand XI: S Bates, S Devine (c), A Kerr, A Satterthwaite, M Green, K Martin (wk), F Mackay, H Jensen, L Tahuhu, J Kerr, H Rowe
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :-

New Zealand - 51/1 (5.1 rpo)  ||  India - 26/2 (2.6 rpo)

Second Powerplay (11-25 Ov)

New Zealand - 84/2 (5.6 rpo)  ||  India - 49/1 (3.3 rpo)

Second Powerplay (26-40 Ov)

New Zealand - 76/1 (5.1 rpo)  ||  India - 65/3 (4.3 rpo)

Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov)

New Zealand - 49/5 (4.9 rpo)  ||  India - 58/4 (8.7 rpo)

New Zealand get their second win of the campaign after beating India by 62 runs at Seddon Park, Hamilton. Fifties from Amy Satterthwaite and Amelia Kerr helped New Zealand post 260 on board, and a brilliant display of pace bowling from Lea Tahuhu helped pile on the pressure for the Indians. Pooja Vastrakar starred with the ball for India picking up 4 wickets, and Harmanpreet Kaur played a fighting knock but it was too much of a task for her. India clash against West Indies on the 12th of March in their next encounter of the World Cup. Catch us then!

Mithali Raj, India captain: "I think after those early wickets, they got a good partnership going and it seemed like 280 would be on the cards. But we did well to pull things back at the end. It was a chaseable score, provided the top order managed the run rate properly. We needed one of the batters to bat deep. There was a lot of extra bounce under lights, nothing unplayable but we could have done better. The batting needs to get better."

Sophie Devine, New Zealand captain: "It was a complete performance. We built partnerships throughout, Amelia Kerr and Amy Satterthwaite batted beautifully. The bowling was outstanding, just didn't give them anything at all. We've got variety and options with our attack and it allows us to be flexible. Today was a more complete performance and hope we can carry it forward to the next game."

Amy Satterthwaite is the Player of the Match.

Amy Satterthwaite: "We wanted to take it as deep as we could, set up a platform from where we could launch. We probably didn't quite do as we would've liked to but in the end it was enough. If I walk off playing the way I want to, regardless of how it went, I can accept that. The timing was there in patches and the bowlers were outstanding, the first 20-odd overs were exceptional, we talked about our starts and we couldn't have asked for anything more."

MatchName: West Indies Women VS India Women
TossDetails: India Women won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: ICC WOMENS WORLD CUP 2022
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of ICC Women's World Cup encounter between India and West Indies. This will be India's third game of the World Cup, having won one and lost one so far. Mithali Raj's side began the tournament with a win over Pakistan, and despite Harmanpreet Kaur's fighting half-century, New Zealand prevailed over India in their second game. West Indies have begun the tournament strongly, with two wins from two. Indian skipper Mithali Raj adds another feather to her cap, with the record of most women's world cup matches as Captain. 

TOSS: India won the toss and elect to bat first. Both sides remain unchanged from their previous game. 

Playing XI:

India: S Mandhana, Y Bhatia, D Sharma, M Raj (c), H Kaur, R Ghosh (wk), S Rana, P Vastrakar, J Goswami, M Singh, R Gayakwad

West Indies: D Dottin, H Matthews, K Knight, S Taylor (c), S Campbelle (wk), C Nation, C Henry, A Alleyne, A Mohammed, S Selman, S Connell
PostMatchCommentary:
First Powerplay (1-10 Ov) :- 

India - 62/2 (6.2 rpo) || West Indies - 81/0 (8.1 rpo)

Second Powerplay (11-40 Ov) :- 

India - 171/1 (5.7 rpo) || West Indies - 80/9 (2.67rpo)

Third Powerplay (41-50 Ov) :- 

India - 84/5 (8.4 rpo) || West Indies - 1/1 

 

A splendid win for India as they get back to winning ways after a comprehensive 155-run win against West Indies, who taste defeat for the first time this tournament. A blazing start in the chase from Deandra Dottin and Hayley Matthews put India on the backfoot initially, but once the partnership was broken by Sneh Rana, India never let the Windies batters settle. A good all-round effort with the ball was backed up by some excellent fielding, and West Indies were eventually bowled out for 162. Sneh Rana picked up 3/22, while Meghna Singh scalped 2 wickets, Pooja Vastrakar, Rajeshwari Gayakwad and Jhulan Goswami took a wicket each. Jhulan Goswami also became the leading wicket-taker in ICC Women's Cricket World Cup with 40 scalps to her name. Earlier, after opting to bat first, Yastika Bhatia provided an explosive start, after which Smriti Mandhana and Harmanpreet Kaur scored magnificent tons to power India to 317/8.

 

Smriti Mandhana is named the Player of the Match.

Smriti Mandhana: " I think scoring a century and not being named player of the match is not something I want, we (Harmanpreet Kaur) both contributed equally, we both are good enough contenders to get it.As a batter, toss is not going to go your way. Last match we did not get going, we learnt from our mistakes, wanted to carry momentum through the 50 overs. We both like chasing and setting target equally.Our strengths are different, she is really good with spin, and I like pace. 

Harmanpreet Kaur: I think set-batter was there this time, last game no one was there to support me,  was also confident about my batting, we were looking for singles and doubles, and looking for boundaries and we were able to do that. Our left and right combination is good.

Stafanie Taylor, Captain, West Indies: " I don't think we bowled the way we wanted to, did not execute. Gave away too many short balls. I thought Harman and Smriti batted really well. The start they (the openers) gave us was brilliant, it was important for one of them to stay there.

Mithali Raj, Captain, India: "Batting and bowling really came out well. Everyone knew the importance of today's game. It required a special effort, we knew West Indies came from 2 wins, we were playing after a big loss. The way Smriti and Harman played was very sensible and they have used their experience. It is good to have youngsters in the squad, they ease out the nerves by cracking a few jokes. Our approach for next games can be consistent."

TossDetails: England Women won the Toss and elected to Field
