TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: England Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
The stage is set for an exciting Women's Twenty20 International match between India and England, taking place at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai. This match is particularly significant as it marks the beginning of a long home season for the Women in Blue.

The team, riding high on confidence after their triumph at the Asian Games, is eager to maintain their winning momentum. They are under the guidance of their new head coach, Amol Muzumdar. This match is not just about winning the day but also about setting a strong foundation for the upcoming T20 World Cup next year. The Indian team, having tasted victory at a major event like the Asian Games, is now more determined than ever to continue their success story. The anticipation for tonight's game is palpable, with the hopes of a nation resting on the Women in Blue, who are all set to kickstart their journey towards the T20 World Cup with a victory.

 

HEAD TO HEAD:

In 27 games, India - 7. England - 20.

 

TOSS:-

HERMANPREET KAUR CALLS RIGHT AT THE TOSS AND ENGLAND WILL BOWL FIRST!!

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, Indian Skipper: "We've decided to field first. Our strategy is to apply pressure on their batters since it's the opening match, and often it's challenging to determine what constitutes a solid score. Additionally, our team excels in chasing scores. Today marks the debut of Shreyanka and Saika. Our goal is to maintain our strong performance here in Mumbai."

 

Heather Knight, English Skipper: "We would have also chosen to bowl first had we won the toss. We've had a few days to get used to the conditions here. We aim to continue developing based on our performance over the last year. We had a successful run during the English summer season, demonstrating significant determination. We're anticipating a large turnout of spectators today and are eager to put up a strong performance."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs):-

England - 44/2 (7.3 rpo, 5x4, 0x6) || India- 53/2 (8.8 rpo, 8x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs):- 

England - 96/0 (10.7 rpo, 12x4, 2x6) || India- 71/2 (7.9 rpo, 6x4, 2x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs):-

England - 57/4 (11.4 rpo, 9x4, 1x6) || India- 35/2 (7.0 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)

 

 

In the first Women's Twenty20 International (WT20I) of the 3-match series between England Women and India Women, England emerged victorious by a margin of 38 runs. The match began with India winning the toss and opting to field. India got off to an excellent start, with Renuka Singh picking up two wickets in the very first over. However, from that point onwards, England's performance remained dominant.

Danni Wyatt and Nat Sciver-Brunt played a pivotal role, forging a formidable partnership of 138 runs. Nat Sciver-Brunt contributed significantly with 77 runs, while Danni Wyatt's 75 runs, combined with Amy Jones' exceptional performance in the death overs, enabled England to post a substantial total of 197 runs. Renuka Singh was the standout performer among the Indian bowlers, claiming 3 wickets.

In response, the Indian women's team initiated their innings positively. However, the English spinners played a crucial role in shifting the momentum in their favor. Sophie Ecclestone's exceptional bowling figures of 3/15 in 4 overs stood out as a highlight of England's bowling performance. Shafali Verma made a notable contribution with a half-century, but it ultimately proved insufficient as England secured a convincing victory. This win provides England with an early lead in the series, setting the stage for an exciting contest in the upcoming matches.


 

Harmanpreet Kaur (India Captain) - "We must absorb these lessons swiftly, as these types of matches are invaluable for our growth before the T20 World Cup. Acknowledging the strength of our opponents in their batting lineup, it's important to note that we've made some adjustments in our bowling department. We are determined to bounce back with greater resilience. While our performance in the match fell short of our expectations, we are committed to analyzing the positives and approaching the next game with a positive mindset. Despite having control of the game after losing a couple of wickets, the final 10 overs didn't unfold as we had strategized."

 

Heather Knight (England Captain) - "The game unfolded positively, aligning with our desired approach. While I would have preferred to bowl first, I'm genuinely satisfied with our batting performance and the total we achieved. It's worth noting that we allowed some extras, an area where improvement is possible, but overall, it was a good game against a strong Indian side."

 

Nat Sciver-Brunt (Player of the Match) - "It's a wonderful feeling to reunite with the England team and deliver a performance of this caliber. We aimed to exhibit courage in our approach, and Danni executed that brilliantly, relieving some of the pressure on me. I'm genuinely delighted with how our partnership unfolded. We each bring our unique strengths to the table, and our partnership functions seamlessly. The pitch was in good condition, offering some assistance to the spinners with a slight hold, and the slower deliveries proved effective, adding a layer of challenge for the opposing batters."

TossDetails: England (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: England Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Women in Blue will face England Women in match number 2 of the 3-match T20 I series at the iconic Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai. The result in the first T20 was not a favourable one for India but Harmanpreet Kaur & Co. would look to pick up from the positives of the first game and bounce back in the second encounter. England after securing a 32-run win in the first match would look to capitalize on the momentum and seal the series. It will be interesting to see India's tactics in this all-important do-or-die encounter.

 

Pitch Report:
Charles Dagnall and Anjum Chopra: "50m and 53m square boundaries, 60m straight down the ground. It looks like a belter of a track. Beautiful batting paradise here at Wankhede. The challenge for the bowlers will be about figuring out where to pitch the ball.
 

 

TOSS:-
England women win the toss and elect to field first!

 

 

Heather Night, England Women Skipper: " We’re going to have a bowl, generally as a side, we prefer chasing targets. Brilliant start from the batting group in the first T20, really pleased with the way we went about our business. A couple of things we could’ve sharpened up with the ball which we will look to work upon. Charlie Dean comes in for Mahika Gaur."

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India Women Skipper: " We were looking to field as well but everyone was ok with whatever. The only thing about bowling second was the dew factor but it wasn’t there in the last game so we are okay with batting first. We had a very positive meeting the other day, we understood our field placements and the areas we need to bowl better. Kanika Ahuja goes out and Titas Sadhu comes in."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs) :-

India- 33/4 (5.6 rpo, 5x4, 0x6)  || England- 49/2 (8.1 rpo, 6x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs) :- 

India- 42/4 (4.6 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)  || England- 33/4 (6.3 rpo, 4x4, 0x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs) :- 

India- 5/2 (4.1 rpo, 0x4, 0x6)

 

India did manage to put up a fight but 80 runs on the board was never going to be enough for a side that bats deep till number 9. England's decision to bowl first paid off as India lost 4 wickets in the powerplay and thereafter failed to make a comeback. Charlotte Dean was the pick of the bowlers getting the wickets of both the openers early in the innings. England too had their struggles with the bat as Renuka Singh made the new ball talk making it difficult when the ball was new. But a partnership between Alice Capsey and Sciver Brunt which added 42 runs made sure that India had hardly any chance to stage a dramatic comeback. Deepti Sharma who was introduced in the ninth over managed to scalp two in two deliveries but that was not enough to restrict the English side under 80. Not clinical but England manage to clinch the game and series on the back of this win.

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India Women Skipper: " Another 30-40 runs could have made a big difference. Proud of my team, we fought till the last run which is a good thing to see. We always want to play with positive intent, but unfortunately, some of us didn't read the ball well and the English Team also bowled well which didn't allow us to score freely. After losing early wickets, we were thinking 120, but couldn't manage. Still proud of our bowlers."

 

Heather Night, England Women Skipper: " A brilliant game of Cricket and the crowd was outstanding too, you felt the pressure out in the middle. Charlie Dean bowled a lot for us in the powerplay, she provides that balance in the side and I thought our bowling unit bowled well. I thought it was quite hard for our openers and I thought Renuka Singh bowled well and the job was to score as many in the powerplay and not lose too many wickets. We have a Test match coming up and we want to win the series 3-0."

 

 

Charlotte Dean  is the Player of the Match

Charlotte Dean: "Really happy with how the game played out for us, the bowlers around me made it very easy for me. In T20 I find it important not to get stuck bowling the same ball again and again and need to vary the pace and see how the batters react. I have a gut feeling on where people are trying to hit me and I plan accordingly. I usually try to target the stumps more often."

TossDetails: England (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: England Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
The excitement is palpable at Mumbai's Wankhede Stadium as the England Women's cricket team and the Indian Women's team gear up for their third T20I clash. England, riding high with a 2-0 lead in the series, is not just looking at a series sweep but also to build momentum ahead of their upcoming challenges. India, although trailing in the series, is eager to showcase their prowess on home ground and gain a morale boost before they head into the test series.The teams will also need to adapt their strategies to contend with the evening dew, which can significantly alter the game, particularly in the later overs.

Today's match transcends a mere contest of skills; it's a showcase of strategic acumen and the indomitable spirit emblematic of women's cricket. Fans are in for a thrilling spectacle, whether it results in England completing a dominant series whitewash or India making a strong statement with a comeback.

 

TOSS:-
England women win the toss and elect to BAT first!

 

Heather Night, England Women Skipper: " We have played some brilliant cricket. The bowlers were superb last evening. We have a few younger players today getting a chance. The crowd keeps getting quiet when we get a wicket. Tremendous atmosphere to play cricket in."

 


Harmanpreet Kaur, India Women Skipper: " We just want to play positive cricket. We were looking to bowl and we got that, we just need to go there and express ourselves. We got some positive results, we need to keep working hard and keep doing the right things. Pleased with our bowling department in particular, they have done well. Batting has been a bit of a concern. Amanjot in for Pooja."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs) :-

England- 32/3 (5.36 rpo, 3x4, 1x6)  || India- 31/1 (5.2 rpo, 5x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs) :- 

England- 44/4 (4.9 rpo, 3x4, 1x6)  || India- 62/1 (6.9 rpo, 6x4, 2x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs) :- 

England- 50/2 (10.0 rpo, 3x4, 2x6)  || India- 34/3 (8.5 rpo, 3x4, 0x6) 

 

India secured a victory in the match, providing a much-needed boost to their confidence as they move towards the Test match. Despite the series win eluding them, this triumph is a step forward for the Indian team. Harmanpreet Kaur, speaking at the toss, expressed satisfaction with certain aspects of their gameplay, despite it being sporadic. This win signifies their ability to consolidate these moments of good cricket into a comprehensive performance. The Indian bowlers were commendable, putting England in a challenging situation early in the game. England's innings could have concluded much earlier if not for Heather Knight's determined fifty, which was crucial in preventing a total collapse. 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India Captain: "I'm feeling okay, these niggles are something I'm used to. As a team, we've shown improvement; game time is crucial for us, and today's performance proves that we'll continue to get better with each match. It was essential for me to stay focused and contribute what the team needed. Facing the spinners was challenging since some balls were turning while others went straight, creating doubt in a batter's mind. In our batting approach, we aimed to carefully select our shots. The left-right combination in our lineup also played a significant role in our strategy." 

Shreyanka Patil, Player of the Match:"I am very happy, as this is the first time I have taken three wickets in a match. My family and coach were watching, which makes this moment even more special for me. I am extremely pleased and intend to keep up this performance. The experiences I gained in the Women's Premier League and with the India-A team have been beneficial. I am very happy to be a part of the Indian squad and am enjoying every moment of it. It's been a huge experience for me, bowling in tandem with Deepthi. She has been a great support, having discussions with me both on and off the field. I am looking forward to bowling more with her. I enjoyed all three of my wickets and it's hard to pick just one as a favorite"

 

Heather Knight, England Captain: "This match provided valuable learning opportunities. We decided to rest some key players and give others a chance to showcase their skills. The crowd was fantastic, and I hope the experience taught our younger players how to maintain composure under pressure. Shreyanka bowled exceptionally well against us. We didn't quite apply ourselves as effectively as we could have. Our batting wasn't up to our usual standard; reaching a score around 140 might have made the game more competitive. Nonetheless, there are many positives to take from this. We managed to put pressure back on the Indian team and learned a lot about our younger players."

Nat Sciver-Brunt, Player of the Series: "I'm really pleased with my performance. I had a bit of a rest tonight but it was still a special and enjoyable game of cricket, especially for the fans. The wicket was slightly slower and less consistent compared to the first game. The Indian bowlers performed superbly, making it challenging for us. In terms of my batting, focusing on the tempo and committing to my shots are aspects I've been working on, and they seem to be paying off. Adaptability is crucial in cricket, as every game presents a different situation."

TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: England Women Tour Of India Test Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the live cricketing action as India Women host England Women for the only Test at Dr DY Patil Sports Academy in Navi Mumbai. Harmanpreet Kaur led India, enter the contest after a win in the third T20I by five wickets, they did lose the first two games but the win in the last game would have boosted their confidence heading into the Test. England, on the other hand, after winning the T20I series will look to carry the form going into the Tests. It will be interesting to see how the two teams will fare.


India Women vs England Women Head-to-Head in Tests:
In as many as 14 games played between the two, India have won two games while England have won just one game. 11 of the games have ended in Draw.

 

TOSS:
India have won the toss and will bat first.

 

PITCH REPORT:

Murali Karthik: "The venue is exceptional, featuring a high-quality surface. There's a uniform spread of grass, notably green in color. The pitch currently feels a bit damp and cool to the touch. Bowlers are likely to find favorable conditions in the initial hour or so, after which the pitch should become more conducive for batting. As for spin, it largely depends on the bowler's mindset. We can expect the pitch to start showing signs of wear towards the end of the third day, potentially influencing the game's progression."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: India- 410/7 (94 Overs, 4.4 rpo, 62x4, 2x6)

Day 2: India- 18/3 (10.3 Overs, 1.7 rpo, 2x4, 0x6) || England- 136/10 (35.3 Overs, 3.8 rpo, 19x4, 0x6)

Day 3: England- 131/10 (27.3 Overs, 4.8 rpo, 21x4, 0x6)


The one-off Test between India and England concluded with a commanding victory for India, triumphing by an impressive margin of 347 runs. Opting to bat first on a favorable batting track, the Indian team displayed a collective batting effort. The team's innings was punctuated by a couple of substantial century stands, propelling them to a formidable total over 400. England's response with the bat was underwhelming. They struggled to find their footing against a disciplined and aggressive Indian bowling attack. The standout performer with the ball was Deepti Sharma, whose exceptional bowling spell yielded a five-wicket haul. Her efforts were instrumental in giving India a significant lead of 292 runs. Despite having the option to enforce the follow-on, captain Harmanpreet Kaur chose to bat again. On Day 2, India Women consolidated their position by adding vital runs, setting England a daunting target of 479 runs. England's second innings mirrored the first, with the batters failing to mount a significant challenge against India's bowling. Pooja Vastrakar and Deepti Sharma were particularly lethal with the ball in the second innings, taking three and four wickets respectively. England's batting lineup seemed bereft of answers to the questions posed by the Indian bowlers, particularly Sharma. Deepti Sharma's match performance was nothing short of extraordinary, contributing a crucial 87 runs with the bat and claiming a total of 9 wickets across both innings. Her all-round brilliance was a pivotal factor in India's dominant win, underlining her as a key player in the team's comprehensive victory.


Heather Knight, England Skipper: "India's performance was truly remarkable, and they really made us suffer. Their first-innings batting was impressive, and we took away many learnings from it. They deserve praise for their play. We faced quite challenging conditions, which were new to us, making scoring runs a difficult task. India stepped up their bowling game even more today compared to the first innings. There are numerous areas for us to work on. There were some exceptional individual performances on our side, notably Bell’s consistent play. Although the match didn't unfold as we hoped, it provided us with valuable lessons and experiences."

 

Deepti Sharma is the player of the match
 

Deepti Sharma: "I'm really feeling good, as I've been eagerly anticipating this day. It's a matter of great pride for us, having successfully carried out our strategies. I'm delighted with the outcomes we achieved. My approach was to maintain composure. We concentrated on building partnerships, and I'm glad we were able to do that effectively. The pitch was quite supportive, so I focused on bowling in the correct zones. Harmanpreet advised me on targeting the right areas, which was very helpful."


Harmanpreet Kaur, Indian Captain: "I'm feeling great. At the beginning of the match, our focus was on strategizing for the win. Fortunately, everything unfolded as we had planned. We had a few days of preparation before this game began, and all the players stepped up, taking responsibility and performing at their best. Our team was well-aware of their plans and implemented them successfully."

TossDetails: Australia (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India Test Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to live coverage of 1st Test Test between India and Australia at the iconic Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai. Women in blue, enter the contest on the back of a solid 347 runs win over England in the recently concluded Test and will be looking to replicate the same kind of performance against the Aussies. Deepti Sharma was the stand-out performer in that game, picking up five wickets and four wickets respectively and scoring a fifty in the first innings while both Satheesh Shuba and Jemimah Rodrigues had a memorable debut as both of them scored fifties in the first innings. Australia, on the other hand, played their last Test game way back in June 2023. They did defeated England by margin of 89 runs in Nottingham and will be looking to play the same kind of game against the home dominant India. Australia have never lost a Test match against India

 

 

Head-to-Head:

In as many as ten games played between the two teams, Australia have emeged victorious on four occasions and India are yet to open their account, rest all six games have ended in draw. While in India both have met four times with all four games ending in Draw 

 

 

Pitch Report |  Julia Price and Rohan Gavaskar."The pitch appears rather flat with a considerable amount of grass covering. Early on, there might be some nip and assistance for the seamers, but the general consensus suggests that it's likely to evolve into a batting paradise after the first 30-45 minutes."

 

                                                                                              

 

TOSS UPDATE:  Australia have won the toss and elected to bat first
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: Australia 219/10 (2.8 rpo, 23x4, 2x6) || India 98/1 (5.2 rpo,17x4,0x6)  

Day 2: India 278/6 (2.8 rpo , 33x4, 0x6)

Day 3: India 30/3 (4.0 rpo , 5x4, 0x6) || Australia 233/5 (2.6 rpo, 26x4, 0x6)

Day 4: Australia 28/5 (1.8 rpo, 4x4, 0x6) || India 75/2 (4.0 rpo , 12x4, 0x6)

 

After the coin flip didn't favor them, the Women in Blue, with an air of unflinching resolve, spectacularly bundled out Australia for a mere 219 on the opening day of the Test. Pooja Vastrakar emerged as a bowling sensation, claiming 4 wickets, while Sneh Rana provided substantial support, taking 3 vital wickets. India's batting order, featuring the dynamic Shafali Verma and Smriti Mandhana at the top, and the robust middle order with Richa Ghosh and Jemimah Rodrigues, coupled with the all-around abilities of Deepti Sharma and Pooja Vastrakar, collaborated to amass a commendable 187-run lead. Their collective efforts highlighted the depth and versatility of the team.

Australia, not to be underestimated, witnessed Tahlia McGrath fighting back valiantly on day three, scoring her second fifty of the match. But India's skipper, Harmanpreet Kaur, wasn't to be outdone, picking crucial wickets in the final session of the penultimate day. The bowlers, especially Sneh Rana, returned with renewed ferocity on the final morning, as Rana added another feather to her cap with a 4-wicket haul, contributing significantly to the team's efforts by dismissing the last five Australian batters for just 28 runs.

Chasing a modest 75, India felt an early tremor as Shafali Verma departed quickly. However, the poised and ever-elegant Smriti Mandhana steered the ship with her fluent batting, ensuring the chase was devoid of further obstacles. As the winning runs were struck, it was a moment of triumph and grace, fittingly sealed by Mandhana's stylish play. Sneh Rana, with a total of 7 wickets across the match, was rightfully adjudged the player of the match, her spellbinding performance a crucial pillar in India's impressive victory. The match was not just a display of cricketing prowess but a narrative of passion, teamwork, and the indomitable spirit of the Women in Blue as they clinched their first-ever test victory against Australia!

 

Alyssa Healy, Australian Skipper: "Experiencing Test cricket firsthand has been an enlightening journey, one filled with challenges and lessons. The prospect of participating in additional Test matches presents an interesting proposition that could have offered further insights into our capabilities and strategies. Despite a challenging start on the first day, the team exhibited commendable resilience and determination throughout the series. This was our first foray into red-ball cricket in these specific conditions, necessitating a rapid and robust adaptation process, in which our players have demonstrated considerable growth and performance. We extend our full commendation to the Indian team for their superior performance, effectively setting a daunting target. Reflecting on our approach, a more robust batting performance on the initial day might have significantly altered the game's trajectory. Securing the toss yet not fully capitalizing on the batting opportunity, combined with our subsequent concession of runs, was pivotal in shaping the series' outcome. Ideally, a score around 300 would have presented a more formidable challenge, emphasizing the critical need for consistent and strategic execution throughout the entirety of the Test. The essence of Test cricket lies in its demand for sustained excellence and adaptability over each day of play. It is crucial for us to assimilate the learnings from our time at the Wankhede Stadium, leveraging the conditions and experiences to bolster our confidence and strategy. The opportunity to engage in both a practice game and this Test match has been invaluable in adjusting to the local conditions. As we look to the future, it is these accumulated experiences and adaptations that will enhance our preparedness and strategic acumen in upcoming matches."

 

Sneh Rana is the player of the match

Sneh Rana: "It's truly an honor to stand here as the recipient of this award, and to celebrate such a significant Test victory. My role extended beyond that of a nightwatchman; batting alongside Smriti Mandhana was a seamless experience, reinforcing my batting capabilities. My focus has always been on taking wickets and making substantial contributions to the team, and I am grateful for the captain's trust in my abilities. While dropped catches are part and parcel of the game, they only strengthen my resolve to perform better. This victory is particularly momentous, marking a rare Test match on Indian soil, placing it among the top achievements for both the team and the fans. It serves as an inspiration for emerging players and underscores the importance and allure of Test cricket in India."

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, Indian Captain: "This achievement is a testament to years of dedication and effort from our entire team and support staff. It's a collective reward for our hard work and perseverance. We aimed to maintain a positive approach in our play, exemplified by our strategic decision to place Richa Ghosh at no.3, known for her aggressive batting. Our focus was on adhering to the basics and executing our roles effectively. Personally, contributing with two crucial wickets was a result of our support staff's encouragement and strategy, emphasizing an offensive rather than a defensive approach from our bowlers. We are immensely grateful to the BCCI and the selectors for this opportunity and their trust in our abilities. Additionally, the consistent presence and support of the crowd over all four days have been incredibly encouraging. Our heartfelt thanks to everyone involved."

TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the first ODI of the three-match series between India and Australia Women at Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai. India won the Test match comprehensively creating history and the Australians would look back to take revenge for their loss while the Indians would try to continue their winning momentum. Who do you think will be in the first xi? Who will kickstart the series with a victory? Let's wait and watch!

 

HEAD TO HEAD:-

India and Australia have clashed against each other on 50 occasions and Australia have emerged victorious 40 times while India have won 10 games. 

 

TOSS:-

HARMANPREET CALLS RIGHT AT THE TOSS AND INDIA WILL BAT FIRST!!
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs):-

India - 49/2 (4.9 rpo, 7x4, 0x6) || Australia - 57/1 (5.7 rpo, 6x4, 2x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs):-

India - 151/5 (5.03 rpo, 16x4, 0x6) || Australia - 184/2 (6.1 rpo, 19x4, 1x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs):-

India - 82/1 (8.2 rpo, 9x4, 2x6) || Australia - 44/1 (6.7 rpo, 7x4, 0x6)

 

In the ODI series opener against Australia, the Indian team opted to bat first. Yastika Bhatia opened the innings for India scoring a good 49 runs in the start after which the Australian bowlers bowled well dismissing the Indian batters. Jemimah Rodrigues's 82 off 77 built the innings well after the loss of a few wickets and Pooja Vastrakar's thundering 62* off 46 took the team to a total to 282. In the second innings, India took the upper hand with Renuka picking the wicket in the very first over. The 1st wicket stand between E Perry (75 off 72) and P Litchfield (78 off 89) was worth 148 runs. Tahlia Mcgrath contributed her best scoring 68* off 55 and the team chased down the score in 46.3 overs.

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, Indian skipper: "I think we put up a good score, but I think the fielding was not up to the mark. It is something that didn't really work well for us. After a while, dew was there but the bowlers were trying their best to attack the stumps. Pooja got us back into the game with her batting. Just need to back ourselves and play that aggressive brand of cricket."

Alyssa Healy, Australian skipper: "Great night for us, nice to get off to a win at the start of the series. I thought we could have kept them around to 250, they put a really good total. It's just about playing straight with the bat. We just played our natural game with the bat."


Phoebe Litchfield is the Player of the Match
Phoebe Litchfield: "This one is pretty special. Perry just played her own game, and struck it straight really well. The whole partnership was really enjoyable. The Pacers got the ball to move in a little bit. Still need to work on a few areas and try not to get out in the 80s."

TossDetails: Australia (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the second ODI against Australia at Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai. After sealing the Test series, the Indian women faced the Australians in the opening ODI at the same venue. India opted to bat first and put up a huge total of 282 runs, but the Australian women chased down the target. Can India turn victorious here and take the decider to the final match?

 

TOSS:-

AUSTRALIA WON THE TOSS AND OPTED TO BAT FIRST!
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs):-

Australia - 49/1 (4.9 rpo, 7x4, 0x6) || India - 50/1 (5.0 rpo, 5x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs):-

Australia - 136/5 (4.5 rpo, 10x4, 1x6) || India - 145/3 (4.8 rpo, 14x4, 0x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs):-

Australia - 73/2 (7.3 rpo, 1x4, 4x6) || India - 60/4 (6.0 rpo, 6x4, 0x6)

 

Australia, after winning the toss and electing to bat first, saw a strong start from Litchfield and Perry, each notching up half-centuries. This strong partnership set a solid foundation for the team. Despite the challenging conditions of the pitch, which favored the spinners, the middle-order batters contributed valuable runs, keeping the momentum going. Deepti Sharma from India exploited the pitch conditions masterfully, claiming five wickets with her spin bowling. Additionally, Alana King's crucial cameo towards the end of the innings boosted Australia to a competitive total, making the most of the 50 overs. On the chase, India faced early setbacks with Bhatia falling early and Mandhana unable to convert her start into a big score. However, Richa Ghosh and Jemimah Rodrigues steadied the ship with a resilient partnership, with Ghosh being particularly aggressive despite battling physical discomfort. Ghosh's innings was especially poignant as she fell just short of a century, a milestone that every batter cherishes. Jemimah's dismissal in the 34th over marked a turning point, as it broke a critical partnership at a crucial juncture of the game. As the innings progressed, the required run rate increased, and despite the efforts, the chase seemed to slip away from India. Ultimately, with 16 runs needed in the last over, the task proved too steep for the lower order, encapsulating the tension and drama that only cricket can offer. Australia will take the win and clinch the series!

 

Alyssa Healy, Australia captain: "It got very close towards the end, but credit to our girls for discovering ways to triumph in difficult situations. We felt our score was somewhat lacking. Alana's hitting brought some momentum. Despite losing many wickets later on, we managed to take wickets and defend our total. There's something about Australian teams; we always hung in there. We maintained our belief that we could win until the very last ball, and that belief underpinned our success. Though we dropped catches and disappointed ourselves in some areas, our energy levels remained high. The past 12-18 months have brought many changes, yet the incoming players have stepped up and played significant roles, which is fantastic."

Harmanpreet Kaur, India captain: "We executed our bowling strategy effectively. It was clear we needed to continuously seek out wickets. There are many positives to take from this. Even though they managed to swing the game in their favor, I'm proud of how my team performed. A little more situational awareness towards the end of the chase would have been beneficial. Richa Ghosh played exceptionally well, with Jemimah Rodrigues supporting her in the middle. We're aware of Australia's extensive batting lineup. Keeping them under 300 was a notable achievement. We believed in our capacity to chase the total but needed to display more tactical acumen during the middle overs. Dropped catches are part of the game; what's important is how we recover from them."

 

Annabel Sutherland is the Player of the Match

Annabel Sutherland: "The game was thoroughly enjoyable, and it truly was a collective effort in the field. We focused on maintaining our composure throughout. Phoebe's catches were nothing short of sensational; she really stood out. Regarding my favorite wicket, I always aim to target the stumps, so bowling out Amanjot felt incredibly rewarding. It's gratifying to execute such plays towards the end, especially when the captain places such trust in me. My approach is to constantly analyze the game and adapt accordingly. I've invested significant time working with the bowling coach, and the accumulation of practice and diverse international experiences has been invaluable. Initially, the pitch presented some challenges; it offered more spin and was slower compared to the previous match. Despite feeling that our score might have been below what we aimed for, Alana's extraordinary performance shifted the momentum in our favor. Phoebe's innings, though challenging, was crucial as she diligently worked to build the total we needed."

TossDetails: Australia (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the third and final One Day International (ODI) between the women's teams of India and Australia at Mumbai's Wankhede Stadium. Australia, having won the first two matches, have already clinched the series, demonstrating remarkable skill, especially in batting. They managed a significant chase in the first game, marking it as the second-highest successful chase in women's ODI history. Despite being down in the series, the Indian team has shown resilience and strength. The two most notable performances from the Indian side: Deepti Sharma's incredible five wicket haul and Richa Ghosh's near-century. However, even with these impressive individual feats, the team struggled under pressure in the final moments of the second ODI, narrowly losing by three runs when they needed 35 off the last five overs. Although the series result is already decided, the upcoming match is far from inconsequential. For India, it's about regaining honor and pride, possibly breaking a long-standing streak since they haven't won a home ODI against Australia since February 2007. For Australia, it's about asserting total dominance and aiming for a clean sweep. Both teams have motivations beyond just the game at hand, with India fighting to rewrite a small piece of history and Australia looking to continue their winning legacy.

 

TOSS:-

AUSTRALIA WON THE TOSS AND OPTED TO BAT FIRST! 

 

Alyssa Healy. "We will have a bat first, The pitch looks quite dry, similar to what we played on in the first ODI. There's a change in the lineup: Darcie Brown is sitting out, and Megan Schutt is returning post a niggle. We're not fans of losing, so, indeed, we're aiming for 3-0. However, we can't underestimate this formidable Indian team." 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur "Great match to kick off the year, exuding positivity. "We were aiming to bowl first. There's one alteration in the team - Sneh Rana is out due to an injury, and in her place, Mannat Kashyap will make her debut. With a bit more consciousness and responsibility, we might have clinched the last match. Nevertheless, it served as a valuable learning experience for us."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs):-

Australia - 55/0 (5.5 rpo, 7x4, 1x6) || India 53/2 ( 5.3 rpo, 8x4,0,x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs):-

Australia - 201/5 (6.7 rpo, 18x4, 3x6) || India 95/8(2.9 rpo, 8x4,0x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs):-

Australia - 82/2 (8.2 rpo, 7x4, 4x6) 

 

 

India suffer a crushing 10-wicket loss - their third biggest defeat by runs in ODIs - as Australia complete a 3-0 series sweep. The home side posted 338 thanks to a rampant opening partnership between Litchfield (111) and Healy (94), later boosted by handy contributions from the middle and lower order.In response, India's chase never gained momentum as wickets tumbled at regular intervals. Opener Yastika fell cheaply while Smriti failed to capitalize on her start. None of the batting unit could construct a substantial, match-saving effort. Australia's disciplined bowling and electric fielding exacerbated the pressure as the visitors crumbled to 166 all out in just 40 overs.The lopsided result means India end the multi-format series on a disappointing note, unable to showcase the positive displays that earned them victory in the lone Test match. For Australia, it caps off a dominant performance on home soil, avenging their earlier defeat. 

 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur: The ODIs didn't pan out as I'd like. We tried hard but fell short. Some excellent individual performances are contrasted by others needing self-analysis to drive improvement against top sides, especially in unforgiving white ball cricket where execution time is scarce. Now we swiftly shift focus to the T20 leg, carrying valuable learnings. The young blood has stood tall already; a huge booster. We know we can match Australia's batting and bowling skills. Gritty fielding remains the differential we must conquer urgently if dreams of overseas series wins will materialize. I remain buoyant. With disciplined execution, our best is yet to come.
 

 

Pheobe Litchfield | Player of the Match and Player of the Series: While these individual accolades make me proud, our team's victory was truly an all-round effort. I've learned immensely analyzing each innings. The first two were challenging but served as blueprint to improve - combined with some luck, I peaked when it mattered most today. Early assessment and adaptability to conditions proved key. Those catches felt natural after endless training reps engraining the instinct, though they sure seemed flashy! A 3-0 ODI sweep feels incredible, especially bouncing back in style from the lone Test defeat. This triumph should launch us onto bigger things in 2024. I’m just tremendously grateful for the opportunity and support systems lifting my game. 

 

 

Alyssa Healy A dominant 3-0 whitewash feels gratifying. With three T20s remaining, we won't relax - it's about sustaining intensity. After subpar fielding initially, we had a point to prove and lifted our game. Litchfield never ceases to amaze me. Bagging two ODI tons at just 20 leaves me shaking my head! She prides herself as our best fielder and fully showcased her skills today. Witnessing her graceful strokeplay up close is truly my privilege. Whenever the team needs someone to stand up, these world class bowlers unfailingly answer the call. Can't ask for better squad depth and talent. We're already refocusing on the T20 mission ahead.

TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the electrifying atmosphere of Dr. DY Patil Sports Academy in Navi Mumbai, as India and Australia gear up for the first of three T20I clashes. India, seeking to overturn a disheartening ODI series, pins hopes on Jemimah Rodrigues' consistent batting brilliance. Meanwhile, Australia, riding high from their recent ODI victories, looks forward to Phoebe Litchfield's continued dominance at the crease. As the teams face off in this highly anticipated encounter, the historical supremacy of Australia in clashes against India, particularly on Indian turf, adds an extra layer of intrigue to this series.


India vs Australia Head-to-Head: In 31 games played between the two teams, Australia has emerged victorious 23 times while the hosts have managed to win on seven occasions, with one game ending in no result. Specifically, in India, the teams have clashed 12 times, with the hosts winning only twice and Australia triumphing in ten games.



PITCH REPORT: Anjum Chopra- "The square boundaries are at 56m and 63m, with a 70m boundary down the ground. The temperatures in Mumbai have dipped, suggesting the likelihood of some dew"

 

TOSS: India won the toss and elected to field first.  

 

                                                                                                               

 

Harmanpreet Kaur | India captain: "We have a lineup of four seamers and two spinners, and we want to take advantage of this chance to field first. It's the perfect time for us to experiment a bit with our strategy."
 

Alyssa Healy | Australia captain: "I'm not overly concerned; we were inclined to bowl first as well. Our batting lineup is robust, and there's ample experience within our team, so everyone is well-versed in their roles".
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs):-

Australia - 33/4 (5.5 rpo, 2x4, 1x6)  || India 59/0(9.83 rpo , 6x4, 2x6) 

Middle Overs (7-15Overs):-

Australia - 86/1 (9.5 rpo 6x4, 5x6)  || India 74/0(8.2 rpo 6x4 , 2x6)

Death Overs (16-20Overs):-

Australia - 22/5 (5.23 rpo, 1x4, 1x6) || India 12/1( 2.4 overs , 5 rpo, 2x4,0x6)

 

 

In a riveting first T20I at Navi Mumbai, India Women decisively turned the tables with a commanding 9-wicket triumph. Spearheaded by Titas Sadhu's exceptional bowling and bolstered by fifties from Mandhana and Verma, India crafted a memorable victory. The hosts not only showcased their batting prowess with a record opening stand but also marked a rare win over Australia in T20Is on home soil, signaling a strong comeback from their recent ODI series defeat. This win sets a vibrant tone for the series, with India leading 1-0 and aiming to maintain this momentum. 

Alyssa Healy| Australia Captain: Today wasn't our best performance. We didn't capitalize with the bat and were off the mark with the ball. Continuously losing wickets affected our momentum. We aim for big scores and need to adapt to conditions better. India's bowling was spot on early, so we'll need to adjust our tactics accordingly. 

 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur| India Captain : Today, we were on point in batting, bowling, and especially fielding, which we've diligently been improving. It's rewarding to see everyone embrace their roles with such enthusiasm. Our fielding placements and last-minute decision to include an extra seamer instead of a third spinner really paid off. 

 

Titas Sadhu|Player of the Match: It's become a bit of a tradition now; I owe a few celebrations for these awards! I've been patient, waiting on the sidelines during the Test and ODI series, so I'm overjoyed to make an impact today. Snagging two early wickets set the tone for me, and I felt in rhythm on this pitch.

TossDetails: Australia (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to live coverage of the second T20I between India and Australia. India rejuvenated from their emphatic victory in the T20I opener, is poised for another spectacular showdown against Australia. The collective prowess of India's bowlers, who restricted Australia to 141, coupled with a dominant batting performance, has set the tone for an intense series. With eyes set on a series victory, the host team leans heavily on their bowling unit, featuring promising talents like Shreyanka Patil and Titas Sadhu, alongside seasoned campaigners finding their groove. The DY Patil Stadium's balanced pitch, with its nuances favoring the batters in the second innings due to dew, awaits another epic encounter. As both teams prepare for the 2nd T20I, the anticipation for a cricketing spectacle under Navi Mumbai's lights is palpable 

In the head-to-head T20I record, Australia historically holds an advantage with 23 victories against India's six from 31 encounters. However, India's recent triumph in the opening match of the current series signifies a potential shift in momentum, indicating a more competitive rivalry ahead. 

TOSS: Australia won the toss and elected to field first 
 



Alyssa Healy, Australia captain: We've decided to bowl first. There's a bit of dew and defending was challenging the previous night. It's crucial tonight to set a good pace early with the bowling. We need to ensure all aspects are on point. The focus is on playing well. Garth will come in for Brown. 
 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India captain: The pitch seems better than before. Opting to bat first, we're aiming to post a strong total. The way Shafali and Smriti excelled in the last game provided valuable insights into the pitch's nature and target areas, which is something I'm still considering.
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs):-

India 33/2 (5.5rpo, 4x4, 1x6) || Australia 47/0 (7.8rpo, 6x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs):- 

India 59/3 (5.5rpo, 6x4, 1x6) || Australia 48/3 (5.3rpo, 7x4, 0x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs):-

India 38/3 (7.6rpo, 4x4, 0x6) || Australia 38/1 (9.5rpo, 3x4, 2x6)

 

 

In the second T20I, India struggled early, losing wickets, with only a resilient Deepti Sharma anchoring the innings to 130. Australia's balanced attack, led by Garth, Wareham, and Sutherland, kept the pressure. Despite early resistance from India, Australia, led by Perry's unbeaten 34 and Litchfield's crucial 18*, chased down the target with an over to spare. The win, marked by Perry's milestone 300th game, leveled the series 1-1, setting up a decider and highlighting areas for India to address, especially in batting, as they prepare for the series finale.

 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur|India Captain: Our total wasn't quite enough, yet our bowlers stretched the game to the 19th over, which is commendable. We need to focus on areas of improvement. Ideally, 150 was our target score, but continuous wicket loss hindered us. These tight matches highlight crucial aspects we need to enhance. With many new players in the squad, I believe the experience will lead to our improvement.

 

 

Alyssa Healy|Australia Captain: The performance wasn't perfect, but securing the victory was vital. We aimed to restrict them below 140, understanding it's a competitive score here. Seeing Garth thrive in these conditions, especially after her WPL performance, is fantastic. We aim for a more clinical approach in the decider.

 

 

Kim Garth|Player of the Match: I'm thrilled with my performance, especially given the supportive bowling conditions. Keeping the stumps in play paid off for me tonight. Bowling in India isn't always easy, but adapting and contributing to the team is what I strive for.

TossDetails: Australia (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Australia Women Tour Of India T20 Series 2023-24
PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the thrilling finale of the Women's T20I series between India and Australia at the Dr. DY Patil Sports Academy in Navi Mumbai. Both teams, tied with a win each, are set for a captivating showdown in this series decider. The 'Women in Blue' clinched a convincing victory against the formidable Aussies in the opener, thanks to Titas Sadhu's outstanding 4/17 bowling spell, earning her the Player of the Match. However, Australia bounced back in the second match, securing a six-wicket win with Kim Garth's exceptional bowling earning her the Player of the Match title. This final game promises to be a riveting contest, determining the ultimate winner of the series.

 

 

In the 33 encounters between these two cricketing powerhouses, Australia has a dominant record with 24 wins, while India has managed eight victories, and one game ended without a result. In matches hosted in India, the two sides have faced off 14 times, with Australia winning 11 of these clashes and India claiming three victories. This historical context sets the stage for an exciting series finale, where past records and current form will clash to crown the champion. 



 

TOSS UPDATE: Australia won the toss and elected to field. 

 

Alyssa Healy|Australia Captain: We've decided to bowl first. We aim to maximize the advantage of the new ball in these early conditions. I've been doing some research on dew; it's certainly been an intriguing journey. Improvement is key for us. Tonight, we're focusing on fine-tuning a few aspects of our game. This past month has been quite enjoyable. We're going with the same lineup as before, unchanged for tonight's game. 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur|India Captain: We had planned to bowl first. Our focus now shifts to our batting; there are specific areas where we need to enhance our performance. An additional 10-15 runs could have significantly impacted the game. It's a great opportunity for us to get the win over them, and we'll put in our utmost effort. We're going into this game with the same team lineup.
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-6 Overs):-

India 51/1 (8.5rpo, 7x4, 1x6) || Australia 54/0 (9.0rpo, 7x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs):- 

India 49/4 (5.4rpo, 3x4, 1x6) || Australia 63/1 (7.0rpo, 9x4, 0x6)

Death Overs (16-20 Overs):-

India 47/1 (9.4rpo, 4x4, 3x6) || Australia 32/2 (8.7rpo, 5x4, 0x6)

 

 

Australia emerged as the dominant force in the third and final T20I against India, in the series. This victory holds historical significance as it marks the first time that India has lost a three-match T20I series after initially taking a 1-0 lead. After losing the toss and being asked to bat first, India witnessed promising starts from their top-order batters, Shafali Verma and Smriti Mandhana. However, both players couldn't capitalize on their starts, unable to convert them into substantial scores. The top-order duo of Jemimah Rodrigues and Harmanpreet Kaur were also dismissed shortly. Despite the early setbacks, India Women managed to stage a commendable recovery, especially considering they were at 66/4 at the halfway point of their innings. The partnership between Richa Ghosh and Deepti Sharma for the fifth wicket provided stability, but it was eventually disrupted by a breakthrough from Wareham. In the latter stages of the innings, Ghosh and Amanjot Kaur struck a few crucial boundaries, helping India breach the 140-run mark.

Australia's reply saw Alyssa Healy taking her time to adapt to the conditions. Once she found her rhythm, there was no looking back. The aggressive Australian captain played her natural game, nearly dismantling the chase within the first 10 overs. Although Healy was dismissed on 38, the decision was inconclusive, and she provided few chances during her innings. Throughout the chase, Beth Mooney's role was pivotal. She held one end, allowing her teammates to contribute and play their part effectively. This strategy worked to perfection, leading Australia to a comprehensive victory. Notably, this series win marked a significant achievement for Alyssa Healy, who was playing her 150th T20I. It was her first T20I series victory as a full-time captain. 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur|India Captain: The past month has seen some quality cricket from us. In white-ball cricket, we've realized the need to be more proactive. We've learned much as a team, especially about fielding and fitness, areas we'll focus on during our break. I'm proud of our youngsters; they've given their all whenever called upon. We always challenge our opponents, and our unity is a strength. There's much to learn from a team like Australia.

 

 

Annabel Sutherland|Player of the Match: Achieving a comprehensive performance and sealing the series win feels great. We reflected on the first game and bounced back strongly. My focus has been on trusting my skills and staying a step ahead with my slower balls. 

 

Alyssa Healy|Australia Captain |Player of the Series: I'm not entirely convinced I deserve the Player of the Series; our bowlers were phenomenal. It's vital to get a solid start in chases, and I'm proud of how we managed the run rate. With 9 bowling options, our confidence in consistently using just 5 in the last games is commendable. I'm fortunate to lead such a talented group. We're now looking forward to a multi-format series against South Africa back home.

MatchName: Board President XI (Women) vs South Africa (Women)
TossDetails: Board President Xi (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: South Africa Women Tour Of India Warm Up Match 2024

TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: South Africa Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the start of the multi-format series between India and South Africa. The series starts with the WODI leg at Bengaluru before moving on to the Only Test and WT20I series at Chennai. Harmanpreet Kaur and the Women in Blue will look to start this 3 match series on a winning note and try out their combinations and preparations as a leadup to next year's WODI World Cup in India.

 

HEAD TO HEAD:

The last time the two teams met was in the ICC Women's World Cup in 2022, where South Africa had edged a last-ball thriller against the Women in Blue. Before that, South Africa had toured India in 2021 where the two teams had played a 5-match series, in which the visitors prevailed 4-1.

 

TOSS:

Harmanpreet Kaur has won the toss and India will bat  first!

 

There is a debut in both teams with Asha Sobhana for India and Annerie Dercksen for the visitors!
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay
India: 51/2 (5.10 rpo, 8x4,0x6) || South Africa:33/2 (3.3 rpo 6x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs
India: 140/4 (4.67 rpo, 9x4,0x6) || South Africa:89/8 (3.2 rpo 9x4, 1x6)

Death Overs
India: 74/2 (7.4 rpo, 6x4,1x6)

 

India take a 1-0 series lead after dominating and getting a big victory here at the Chinnaswamy stadium in Bengaluru. After winning the toss and electing to bat , the Women in Blue lost 2 wickets inside the Powerplay but Smriti Mandhana scored 5 boundaries to help India score 51 inside the Powerplay, after which the Indian vice-captain continued with the run-flow and stitched up crucial 50 run partnerships with Deepti Sharma (in her 200th International match ) and Pooja Vastrakar, and Mandhana notched up her first WODI  in Indian soil , to help India post a total of 265/8 after 50 overs.

 

In the 2nd innings the Women in Blue were on target from the get-go, with Renuka Thakur removing the South African skipper in the first over and Pooja Vastrakar also striking inside the Powerplay, after which the Indian spinners strangled the chase highlighted by debutant Asha Sobhana, who picked up 4 wickets, helping India win by a huge margin of 143 runs in the 1st WODI 

 

Laura Wolvaardt, South Africa Skipper: "Not the ideal way to start the series, however, I think there were a few positives throughout. I thought 260 was a fairly decent score. We just needed one person to bat through, and it was fairly chasable. I think we could have been a little bit better with our control but I thought 265 wasn't too bad. I think being 30 for three is probably not ideal and we definitely need to regroup."


Harmanpreet Kaur, India Skipper: "It was a good team performance. We showed good energy. We have a long batting order and we know everybody cannot contribute. 2-3 players do the job and today Smriti, Deepti and Pooja did that for us. The allrounders love the format as you have time to execute your plans. Very happy with their performance and contribution to the team. We already discussed going with 5 bowlers and maybe myself, Hemalatha or Shafali will bowl 2 or 3 overs if needed. Hoping that Pooja is fine and the injury is not that bad."


Smriti Mandhana is the Player of the Match

Smriti Mandhana: "I'm really happy that I could contribute and as we discussed, starting the series well is the most important thing. So I'm really pleased that we achieved a hundred-plus run victory, nothing could be better than that. Today it was about playing the situation again. We lost a few wickets in the middle, so it was crucial to build a partnership. Credit to Deepti and Pooja, whenever they came in they kept the scoreboard moving which really helped us as set batters."

TossDetails: India (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: South Africa Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the start of the multi-format series between India and South Africa. The series starts with the WODI leg at Bengaluru before moving on to the Only Test and WT20I series at Chennai. Harmanpreet Kaur and the Women in Blue will look to start this 3 match series on a winning note and try out their combinations and preparations as a leadup to next year's WODI World Cup in India.

 

HEAD TO HEAD:

The last time the two teams met was in the ICC Women's World Cup in 2022, where South Africa had edged a last-ball thriller against the Women in Blue. Before that, South Africa had toured India in 2021 where the two teams had played a 5-match series, in which the visitors prevailed 4-1.

 

TOSS:

Harmanpreet Kaur has won the toss and India will bat  first!

 

There is a debut in both teams with Asha Sobhana for India and Annerie Dercksen for the visitors!
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay
India: 51/2 (5.10 rpo, 8x4,0x6) || South Africa:33/2 (3.3 rpo 6x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs
India: 140/4 (4.67 rpo, 9x4,0x6) || South Africa:89/8 (3.2 rpo 9x4, 1x6)

Death Overs
India: 74/2 (7.4 rpo, 6x4,1x6)

 

India take a 1-0 series lead after dominating and getting a big victory here at the Chinnaswamy stadium in Bengaluru. After winning the toss and electing to bat , the Women in Blue lost 2 wickets inside the Powerplay but Smriti Mandhana scored 5 boundaries to help India score 51 inside the Powerplay, after which the Indian vice-captain continued with the run-flow and stitched up crucial 50 run partnerships with Deepti Sharma (in her 200th International match ) and Pooja Vastrakar, and Mandhana notched up her first WODI  in Indian soil , to help India post a total of 265/8 after 50 overs.

 

In the 2nd innings the Women in Blue were on target from the get-go, with Renuka Thakur removing the South African skipper in the first over and Pooja Vastrakar also striking inside the Powerplay, after which the Indian spinners strangled the chase highlighted by debutant Asha Sobhana, who picked up 4 wickets, helping India win by a huge margin of 143 runs in the 1st WODI 

 

Laura Wolvaardt, South Africa Skipper: "Not the ideal way to start the series, however, I think there were a few positives throughout. I thought 260 was a fairly decent score. We just needed one person to bat through, and it was fairly chasable. I think we could have been a little bit better with our control but I thought 265 wasn't too bad. I think being 30 for three is probably not ideal and we definitely need to regroup."


Harmanpreet Kaur, India Skipper: "It was a good team performance. We showed good energy. We have a long batting order and we know everybody cannot contribute. 2-3 players do the job and today Smriti, Deepti and Pooja did that for us. The allrounders love the format as you have time to execute your plans. Very happy with their performance and contribution to the team. We already discussed going with 5 bowlers and maybe myself, Hemalatha or Shafali will bowl 2 or 3 overs if needed. Hoping that Pooja is fine and the injury is not that bad."


Smriti Mandhana is the Player of the Match

Smriti Mandhana: "I'm really happy that I could contribute and as we discussed, starting the series well is the most important thing. So I'm really pleased that we achieved a hundred-plus run victory, nothing could be better than that. Today it was about playing the situation again. We lost a few wickets in the middle, so it was crucial to build a partnership. Credit to Deepti and Pooja, whenever they came in they kept the scoreboard moving which really helped us as set batters."

TossDetails: South Africa (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: South Africa Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome, everyone, to the live coverage of the second One Day International between the India Women and South Africa Women. In the first match, the home team, India, secured a significant victory over the visitors, thanks to a brilliant century from Smriti Mandhana and economical bowling from the Indian spinners. The South African Women's team fell short by 143 runs in their chase of a 266-run target. The Women in Blue aim to build on this momentum and clinch the series, while Laura Wolvaardt's side will be looking to rebound and keep their hopes alive.

 

 

HEAD TO HEAD:
India Women have come out victorious on 16 occasions while South Africa Women have clinched 12 games from the 29 ODI clashes between the teams. One Match ended in No result.

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Dane van Niekerk: " Having looked at the boundary dimensions, it is 58m and 56m on the square fence and straight down the ground is 66m. We can see more grass compared to the last match here. It's dry, firm and looks pretty solid. Suggesting good heavy rolling since last two days. Spin won't play a role as big as the last match. There'll be a lot more runs on offer. If I was the captain, I would chase. We can even expect 300 runs on this track."

 

TOSS:
South Africa Women has won the toss and have elected to   first

 

Laura Wolvaardt, South Africa Women Skipper:  We're going to bowl first today. It's the first toss I've won in a while. The pitch looks a bit greener, so we hope it skids nicely later under the lights. We've made two changes today: Nadine de Klerk is back from illness and replaces Shangase, and Mieke de Ridder will make her debut as Jafta suffered a mild concussion during training yesterday."

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India Women Skipper: " We wanted to bat first. In the last game, we managed to put 260 runs on the board. Today's pitch looks even better, so we aim to adopt an even more positive approach as a batting unit. Renuka is resting today, and Arundhati is making her debut in her place."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-

IND- 28/0 (2.8 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)  || SA-52/1 (5.2 rpo 8x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs) :-

IND- 179/2 (5.97 rpo, 17x4, 3x6) || SA-171/2 (5.7 rpo 18x4, 2x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs) :-

IND- 118/1 (11.8 rpo, 14x4, 5x6)  || SA-98/3 (9.8 rpo 5x4, 5x6)

 

 

 

In the second One Day International between India Women and South Africa Women, India posted an impressive total of 325/3 in their 50 overs. Smriti Mandhana shone with a magnificent 136 off 120 balls, supported by Harmanpreet Kaur's unbeaten 103 off 88 balls. Richa Ghosh and Dayalan Hemalatha contributed with 25 and 24 runs, respectively. The South African bowlers struggled, with Nonkululeko Mlaba being the standout with 2 wickets for 51 runs.

In reply, South African women put up a valiant fight, scoring 321/6 in their 50 overs, just falling short of the target. Laura Wolvaardt played a captain's knock, remaining unbeaten on 135 off 135 balls, while Marizanne Kapp provided strong support with 114 off 94 balls. Despite their efforts, the Indian bowlers, led by Deepti Sharma and Pooja Vastrakar, managed to contain the South African chase. Deepti Sharma took 2 wickets for 56 runs, while Vastrakar also claimed 2 wickets for 54 runs. Ultimately, India Women clinched the victory by 4 runs in a thrilling contest. India has also sealed the three-match series leading 2-0!  

 

 

Laura Wolvaardt, South Africa Women Skipper:  "I'm extremely proud of the group for getting us to this position. At the halfway stage, it would have been easy to retreat with such a huge total on the board, but Kappie did an excellent job of alleviating the pressure. We were limited in our bowling options today, and India executed their yorkers well at the death, while we conceded a few too many runs in that phase. A narrow four-run loss makes you scrutinize every little detail, which can be frustrating. However, we'll focus on the positives; this was our best batting performance in a long time."
 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur is Player of the Match 

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, India Women Skipper: " I think it's a great achievement for women's cricket to have nearly 650 runs in the game. South Africa played really well. Our batting was on point, especially in the initial stages when the ball was moving; both openers showed great resilience and didn't throw their wickets away, making it easier for us later. We did make some errors while bowling, not always bowling according to the field. I know it's a batting track and not easy to bowl on, but we need to learn from this and adjust our strategies if we encounter similar conditions again. In our camp, all the batters tried their hand at bowling. Smriti even asked me to tell Amol that she's a great bowler, which shows how much that camp helped us. Shafali also did well with the ball, and it was good to see Smriti get a wicket. Deepti is always our strike bowler, someone who consistently takes wickets for the team. Today, I told her she was going to get a wicket when Kapp and Laura were batting, and she delivered."

TossDetails: South Africa (Women) Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: South Africa Women Tour Of India Odi Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the 3rd & Final WODI of the series between India and South Africa at the M. Chinnaswamy stadium in Bengaluru. The Women in Blue will look to make it a clean sweep against South Africa and look to head into the Test and WT20I legs with momentum. The Harmanpreet-led side dominated the first WODI and etched a nervy thriller in the 2nd game of the series, with vice-captain Smriti Mandhana notching up centuries in both games and skipper Harmanpreet Kaur also getting a hundred in the previous match. Can Smriti get her third consecutive hundred and make her way into the record books as the player with the most WODI hundreds for India today?

 

PITCH REPORT:

WV Raman & Dane van Niekerk: "It's 59m on the offside, 57m on the leg side and 66m down the ground. There was variable bounce on the wicket in the first ODI and we are back on the same wicket for this game. There's less grass on this wicket and it's going to crumble later on. Overall, it's a good wicket and there are a lot of runs to be had."

 

TOSS:

South Africa have won the toss and will bat first!
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay: (1-10 Overs)

South Africa - 46/0 (4.6 rpo, 6x4, 0x6) || India - 53/0 (5.3 rpo, 7x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs: (11-40 Overs)

South Africa - 125/5 (4.2 rpo, 9x4, 1x6) || India - 161/3 (5.4 rpo, 14x4, 1x6)

Death Overs: (41-50 Overs)

South Africa - 41/3 (4.1 rpo, 2x4, 1x6) || India - 6/1 in 1 Over (9.0 rpo, 0x4, 1x6)

 

India continues their domination in the series and wins the final WODI by 6 wickets and 56 balls to spare ! After winning the toss and opting to bat in the final WODI, South Africa got off to a great start in the Powerplay, scoring 46 runs without losing a wicket and went on to notch up a 100-run partnership for the opening wicket, after which the Harmanpreet Kaur led side put the brakes on the scoring, picking up 5 wickets in the space of 41 runs led by Arundhati Reddy's crucial double caught & bowled, after which India built on the momentum to restrict the visitors to 215/8. In the chase, Smriti Mandhana and Shafali Verma got India off to yet another powerful start in the Powerplay, scoring 53 runs without losing a wicket, after which the Indian vice-captain continued her purple patch and went on to notch up her third consecutive half-century of the series. In the process, Smriti Mandhana also etched her name in the record books , becoming the player with the most runs in a 3-match WODI bilateral series. Skipper Harmanpreet Kaur also provided the finishing touches to help India dominate the game and series and complete a 3-0 whitewash . Join us on 28th June for the first day of the Test match!

 

Laura Wolvaardt, South Africa Captain: "Didn't have enough runs on the board, we had a good start and unfortunately lost many wickets in the middle and did not build any partnerships. We have played good cricket in patches and need to be a lot more consistent. We don't play too much red-ball cricket, have a few days to refresh and get onto the Test plans. I am really excited and looking forward to it."

 

Harmanpreet Kaur, Indian Captain: "The last few camps we had gave us a lot of confidence. Credit goes to the bowlers, they have been outstanding today. I tell the bowlers to stick to their strength and just give them confidence and the field placement as they want. We will enjoy our win tonight, but there is a Test match and then a T20 series coming up, so we need to think about our plans for that as well."

 

Deepti Sharma is the Player of the Match

Deepti Sharma: "Really enjoyed bowling today and we executed our plans perfectly. I always back my stock ball and stay ready for all kinds of situations. Sometimes you need to contain the batters, so I try to read the situation, keeping the pitch and conditions in mind as well."

 

Smriti Mandhana is the Player of the Series

Smriti Mandhana: "Unfortunate to miss out on a 100 today. The bowlers bowled well and for us, it was just about applying ourselves with the bat. We have a series left, the Asia Cup and then the World Cup. I tried my hand in the previous game and got lucky, always good to add a different skill and if my bowling comes off then it is the best feeling."
